text: today on x cast President Obama prepares
to address the nation Monday night on
America's role in the Libyan conflict as
NATO takes the lead and the u.s.
maintains it has no plans to intervene
in other conflicts in the Middle East
even as the situation in Syria escalates
President Obama will announce tonight
that the United States and its coalition
has turned over command of the Libya
military campaign to NATO our goal is to
help protect civilians and population
centres from attacks or that other
threat of under attack in Libya the US
will still be very much involved and
indeed will still take a very large role
in this given the size of the US
military and the fact that the US
continues to play a lead role in NATO
but in terms of actually using cruise
missiles for example or American fighter
jets targeting tanks or artillery the
bulk of that will pass over to other
NATO partners what it means for the
mission itself is not yet totally clear
but it may not mean as much as it might
imply since the the purpose of the
mission which is to protect civilians
and to attack Qadhafi's army whenever he
attacks civilians will remain unchanged
so the nature of the actual battle
that's underway in Libya probably won't
look much different the one issue that
may crop up in the coming days is that
NATO as a coalition of 28 countries
you'll have to satisfy all the members
of NATO as to the nature and the conduct
of the of the campaign and there are
some members of NATO such as Turkey that
have expressed some reluctance about
some forms of military engagement so
politically it may be a slightly more
unwieldy structure but for the United
States is very important to do this as
President Obama has promised from the
outset that this would be a limited
gagement and that the US would hand over
prime responsibility after a few days
what remains to be seen is how the
operation plays out particularly if it
lasts for months or even through the end
of the year as Secretary gates and
Secretary Clinton suggested it might
over the weekend now the no-fly zone and
even the humanitarian side will have to
be sustained for some period of time the
longer it it lasts longer it drags out
the more there's potential for dissent
among the partners who are involved in
it what we hope and expect is that there
will be a cessation of violence and that
there will be a peaceful solution to the
crisis a transition to democracy which
is what's the people of Libya want and
in Syria it was another day of clashes
between protesters and government forces
in the border city of Daraa where more
than 60 people have been killed Michael
slackman reports on why the u.s. is not
planning on a military intervention I
think the calculation was made the
colonel qaddafi is pretty much gone
there's an international consensus to
try to get him out the opposite
calculation is made regarding President
Assad the present President Assad will
survive this and therefore it's not in
the United States interest to appear to
come out too strongly against them if
you're looking for consistency in
American foreign policy in the Middle
East and North Africa you're simply not
going to find it at a time when nearly
every country is experiencing some kind
of upheaval and the US will look at each
country depending on its interest in
that country that said there's two main
interests in Libya one is humanitarian
which was stated by the government the
other is oil Western Europe and the
United States want the flow of oil to
continue in Libya's now in Syria of
course the circumstances are quite
different there is no international
consensus and there certainly is no
regional consensus for any kind of
military intervention the human right
aspect actually still exists the Assad
family has killed more Syrians certainly
over the last
for years then where McCarthy has in
Libya but the Syrian regime maintains
the capacity to retaliate against US
interests as well as US allies so israel
could certainly face retaliation if
there were any kind of military
intervention syria is known to have one
of the largest stockpiles of chemical
and unconventional weapons in the Middle
East so we're talking there could be
very serious repercussions
